awd_titl_txt: Control and function of chromatin-mediated gene silencing in fungi
awd_abstract_narration:
Normal development relies on regulated gene expression, which in many organisms is achieved by protein complexes that alter the structure of chromatin to silence or activate genes. Chromatin consists of DNA packaged together with histone and other proteins. How Polycomb Repressive Complexes (PRCs) silence genes that are important for development is not completely understood in any organism. This project seeks to uncover how specific genes are targeted and inactivated by PRCs, using fungi as convenient model systems. Societal impacts will be via a combination of research on gene regulation, natural products, biofuels and the discovery of putative fungal pathogenicity factors. The broader impact of the work will also provide hands on laboratory education of undergraduates via intensive long-term research projects. Other outreach efforts include two-day genomics workshops for high school teachers and presentations to the general public.

This project addresses mechanisms of chromatin-based gene silencing by PRC2 and H3K27 methylation in the filamentous fungus, Fusarium graminearum. Using a forward genetics screen, two novel chromatin proteins that impact H3K27 methylation (DIS2 and DIS10) were discovered. The main objectives of this work are to uncover the mechanism for PRC2 targeting and the composition of PRC2 complexes. The main hypotheses for the current project are: (1) Fusarium DIS2 and DIS10 use their putative chromatin-binding motifs to interact with specific regions on histones or other chromatin proteins to target the core PRC2 to chromatin segments that will be enriched for H3K27 trimethylation; (2) targeting is based on portable, nucleic acid-based signals. Core PRC2 subunits are regulated by DIS2 and DIS10 and themselves regulate a large network of transcription factors and major regulators of signal transduction. Completion of this project will result in gaining insights into the global H3K27 methylation network. Methods used to achieve the aims are: (1) forward and reverse genetics by undirected selections and screens, gene deletions, and site-directed mutagenesis; (2) biochemistry by chromatin immunoprecipitation, genome-wide expression analyses and mass spectrometry; (3) biophysical studies to probe interactions between DIS2 or DIS10 and histone or other chromatin proteins, and (4) cytology by examination of "silencing bodies" (containing PRC2) in association with DNA. In combination, these techniques will allow identification and characterization of PRC2 signals and novel proteins involved in gene silencing. By studying mechanisms of PRC2 targeting, this research will provide key knowledge on chromatin-mediated silencing in eukaryotes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed mechanisms of chromatin-based gene silencing by H3K27 methylation in filamentous fungi. By forward genetics, we previously discovered two chromatin proteins required for gene silencing, "Defective in Silencing 2" (DIS2) and DIS10. We showed that Fusarium Dis2 (aka Epr1 or BP1) and Dis10 use chromatin- or DNA-binding motifs to interact with methylated histone H3 or specific DNA segments, respectively. We found that Dis2 is required for normal H3K27me3 levels across bulk chromatin, both by western analyses and chromatin immunoprecipitation. This suggests that Dis2 acts upstream or at the same level as the H2K27 methyltransferase complex, PRC2, and is not, as had been previously suggested, a downstream effector of silencing. We showed that Dis2 binds to PRC2, and we now hypothesize that it increases residence time of PRC2 on specific regions to allow for targeted H3K27 methylation activity. Thus, if Dis2 is absent, PRC2 activity is no longer targeted and H3K27me3 is mislocalized into euchromatic regions, resulting in the observed increase of H3K27me3 levels in bulk chromatin. In vitro, Fusarium Dis2 can bind to H3K4me3, H3K9me3, and H3K27me3 but this has not been established in fungal cells. Because all PRC2 components (Kmt6, the methyltransferase, as well as Eed and Suz12, two allosteric regulators), can be analyzed by cytology in Fusarium we showed that all PRC2 subunits are required for normal distribution of DIS2 in silencing bodies. We also showed that, surprisingly, wildtype Kmt6 decreases chromosome stability under normal growth conditions in the fungus Zymoseptoria tritici. While mutants that are defective in H3K9me3 resulted in widespread chromosome aberrations, duplications and chromosome loss, kmt6 mutants showed fewer such events, yet only a few genes were de-repressed in kmt6 mutants. Thus, we separated, for the first time, chromatin stability functions from transcriptional regulation functions of PRC2. In follow-up work, we found that another repressive histone mark, H4K20me3, catalyzed by Kmt5, controls Ash1-mediated H3K36 methylation and at least some H3K27 methylation. This was an unexpected and completely novel finding, and we followed up with studies in Fusarium and Neurospora where H4K20me3 did not have the same repressive effects. In Zymoseptoria, we showed that absence of the H3K36me3 “reader” protein, Eaf3, altered H4K20 and H3K27 methylation levels; the latter was also true in Fusarium Cdp6/Eaf3 mutants. We also identified additional protein complexes that affect PRC2 activity or gene silencing in H3K27me3 regions: (1) The chromatin remodeling factor ISWI contributes to normal, region-specific H3K27me3 levels in Fusarium, most likely by affecting kmt6 transcript levels, and based on studies with an isw1 kmt6 double mutant the Isw1 and Kmt6 regulons are only partially overlapping; (2) mutation of the catalytic subunit of the H3K4 methyltransferase, Kmt2 (Set1), resulted in upregulation of genes in regions that are usually enriched with H3K27me3; (3) we identified the HDA-1 histone deacetylase complex as a likely contributor to normal H3K27 methylation in Fusarium. This grant also supported key activities that ensured broader impacts outside of the broad scientific merit. Understanding how repressive chromatin marks, like H3K27me3, are controlled in several different fungi is of both biomedical and industrial importance. Both Fusarium and Zymoseptoria are devastating plant pathogens on cereal crops, especially wheat, and understanding their life cycle and gene regulation in greater detail will allow for better control in the field. Regions of facultative heterochromatin are enriched for gene clusters that control both effectors for plant and animal infection by fungi and the production of secondary metabolites that can become useful medicines in the long run. This project was instrumental for the education of one graduate student, and three post-doctoral trainees. Over twenty undergraduate scientists helped to carry out the biochemical, genetic, and cytological work; they generated libraries of histone H3 and H4 mutants that will be useful for the research community and worked on understanding the function of Dis2 and Dis10. Almost all students were recruited via our experiential learning lab courses in which we generated dis2, histone H3 and H4 point mutants, or deletions of over thirty genes encoding chromatin-related proteins. These courses are specifically designed to improve student retention in STEM fields.
